values:
This space is for reading other people's LJs and commenting and the very occasional flocked post.

My actual content is all over at Shaken & Stirred.
The full details are over here, but I cannot be stopped from posting here too. I have accepted an offer of representation from the fabulous Jenn Laughran of the Andrea Brown Literary Agency. Whee!

Well, actually she's not all that great at the literal ass-kicking, though willing to give it an old college try in a pinch. Anyway, one of my JoNo compatriots posted a link to a hero image generator, and I spent awhile yesterday creating one of my book's Alexa. I can't figure out how to actually save the image in a way I can just quickly paste it in here in its full glory, but I did print a copy and scan it and the result will appear below. (Complete with lines in the background from the crappy printer!)

The main thing you can't see as well in the scan is the dark olive tone of her skin. ANYWAY, it's not as if we go around in our novels talking about what our characters look like all the time (at least, I don't), but I have a pretty good image of them all as I'm working. And it actually felt useful (not to mention fun) to have to figure out her warddrobe and al the other million details. And now she's watching me...

So, without further ado, Alexa Johnson, aka Medea's daughter, aka the heroine of Saving the Witch.

For those who don't read the usual blog, here's a reproduced entry:

If you happen to be radio-friendly, I'll be on NPR's Weekend Edition tomorrow morning (about 40 minutes into the first hour of the broadcast) discussing the new Modern Library edition of Anne of Green Gables.

X-posted from Shaken & Stirred:

Christopher is trying to finish an end of the semester project for his Linguistics class, looking at the speaking traits of people with Asperger's Syndrome. He has designed a quick, handy online survey and needs responses from folks with an AS diagnosis OR who live with someone with AS and are familiar with their conversational style.

Anonymous, of course, and you will earn both our undying gratitude -- anonymously -- for filling it out. Please pass on to anyone you know who fits the bill.
live in Maine District 38, clearly, you're going to vote for Carrie Jones, right? I thought so.
Can anyone think of a REALISTIC young adult novel by an AMERICAN writer that uses omniscient point of view from the last 20 years? It can be limited omniscient or the big old editorial kind. Danke.

(X-posted at my Real Blog.)

I'm about to start semester the third in the MFA in Writing for Children and Young Adults at the fabulous Vermont College of Fine Arts (a program I highly recommend). Anyway, the third semester is when you do your critical thesis and I'm putting together the reading list for the bibliography of mine, attempting to get a headstart on things. What I'd love from you smarty smart peeps, are your recommendations of any and all (good, bad, indifferent) young adult fantasies with strong political overtones.

Nothing's too obvious to mention, because I'm interested in being as comprehensive as possible and my ability to overlook stuff should never be discounted. And although I'm more focused on relatively current work (last 10-15 years), classics are fine too as I haven't fully established the scope yet.

Take that,
snurri
!

You are The High Priestess Science, Wisdom, Knowledge, Education. The High Priestess is also associated with the moon however and can also indicate change or fluxuation, particularily when it comes to your moods. What Tarot Card are You?Take the Test to Find Out. Why yes, I am putting off delving into The Inbox That Ate My Life. Y tu? What are you putting off today?

ETA: Holy shit! This frighteningly reflects reality. Except for the high priestess part.

Because and are doing it:


You are The Star


Hope, expectation, Bright promises.


The Star is one of the great cards of faith, dreams realised


The Star is a card that looks to the future. It does not predict any immediate or powerful change, but it does predict hope and healing. This card suggests clarity of vision, spiritual insight. And, most importantly, that unexpected help will be coming, with water to quench your thirst, with a guiding light to the future. They might say you're a dreamer, but you're not the only one.


What Tarot Card are You?
Take the Test to Find Out.

So the winking Ren-Faire crasher me was freaking the real me out. Plus, I had no idea there was an option to do the thriller dance! Chris Barzak, this one's for you and luck tonight at the big awards:

I figured I deserved some brainless time-wasting... The background is for
giantsloth
.


(The winking gets a tad creepy so don't look directly at it!)

that watching every video of The Clash on YouTube is not procrastination, but a necessary activity.

Updated: What's a wolf without a pack? 

I've moved on to Emily Haines vids.
My SFF reviews are up at Book World this week. That was pretty fun to do.

Houston, we have a first packet. 

Now, TV, wine, sleep. Wake up to snow.

World-building: hyphenated, two words sans hyphen or one word?

I'm in
sallytuppence
's Virtual Lulu's trying to write a paper and google is failing me miserably. I can find many examples of each.

Updated: I think I'll just have to pick one and go with it... and, no, it's not an entry in either the Encylopedia of Fantasy or of Science Fiction. But the paper draft is done, done, done.

My classmate
kateangelella
has succumbed to the pressure and started an LJ. In addition to having a beautiful name, she's hilarious and an awesome YA writer. Go say hi and friend her!

It is. 

This actually works perfectly, since my protag's mom is a chef (and a witch, but who's counting?). And it being on the Continental Divide is useful too. 

Thanks to all y'all for the suggestions.

a weird town in New Mexico that is smallish and is NOT Roswell? (Although Roswell might be kind of fun for my purposes, but I want to see if there's anything else suitable and lesser known first.) 

My characters will be wandering in from the desert.

Offered without comment...
(Via
snurri
.)

You are The High Priestess

Science, Wisdom, Knowledge, Education.

The High Priestess is the card of knowledge, instinctual, supernatural, secret knowledge. She holds scrolls of arcane information that she might, or might not reveal to you. The moon crown on her head as well as the crescent by her foot indicates her willingness to illuminate what you otherwise might not see, reveal the secrets you need to know. The High Priestess is also associated with the moon however and can also indicate change or fluxuation, particularily when it comes to your moods.

What Tarot Card are You?
Take the Test to Find Out.

Why yes, I am putting off delving into The Inbox That Ate My Life. Y tu? What are you putting off today?

And it's even writing-related! I need warm boots for my first MFA residency in Vermont this January. The dynamite haddayr pointed out some excellent options at Zappos and I think I've narrrowed it down to the following fabulous selections: 



  • crunchy
  • tall
  • flowery
  • gray
  • these (I keep going back and forth between tusk and rootbeer -- possibly too short; opinions requested, but I kinda like these best at the moment) (or here's a taller version)
  • taller

Which is where you come in. Preferences? Other candidates?

Updated: Thanks to all who played! Cleary, crunchy has won the fantasy boot competition. But the actual cold weather-livers have confirmed my opinion that these or a taller version of these (why is the taller version not available in tusk? gnash) are probably going to work best ... especially when wearing pants. I like pants. So I'm gonna try those first and see if they work. Next stop: warmer coat that does not look like a Stay Puft Marshmallow Man costume!

I love it when these things are abso-mo-luuutely wrong:
What American accent do you have?
Your Result: The Midland

"You have a Midland accent" is just another way of saying "you don't have an accent." You probably are from the Midland (Pennsylvania, southern Ohio, southern Indiana, southern Illinois, and Missouri) but then for all we know you could be from Florida or Charleston or one of those big southern cities like Atlanta or Dallas. You have a good voice for TV and radio.

The West
The South
Philadelphia
Boston
The Northeast
The Inland North
North Central
What American accent do you have?
Take More Quizzes

HowManyOfMe.com
There is:
1
person with my name
in the U.S.A.
How many have your name?

(Via Barb Gilly.)

Because it wouldn't fit on my Typepad!

Barometric pressure feels like witchcraft. We had huge freaky storms last night, and it looks like we're now having them again. We woke up to news reports about people being rescued from cars and drunk college students being swept away into storm tunnels. Water was over the pilot light, but it's all fixed now and we're unscathed.

My JoNoWriMo week was lametastic, since I was too busy to breathe. We even canceled a trip to N.C. this weekend, because life and work just didn't permit. But I managed to get back on track today, at least in terms of new words. This section of the book involves a huge scene at a White House state dinner and it is hard, hard, hard to manage so far. But I did get to write about Sargent's Teddy Roosevelt today.
16,953 / 65,000
(26.1%)
Oh, and I've figured out some big structural things, where this goes and that goes in relation to everything else. Progress is progress, no matter how it feels.

With only minimal pre-work procrastination (downloading of Charlotte Gainsbourg MP3s), the quietish, emotional turmoilly chapter is complete*. Yay!
15,122 / 65,000
(23.3%)
And I got my Vermont acceptance letter and related materials in the mail today, bearing the happy additional news that I got a small (but nice nonetheless) merit-based scholarship for my first semester. So yay diex! We did my FAFSA crap for loans (financial aid just doesn't exist anymore, does it?).

I'm feeling better and we're off to visit my parents for the night. Life is good.

*For now

Forgot to mention that I received a nice rejection from Gordon for the Slush Bomb Story a couple of days ago; liked the characters and thinks they will play very well in the YA market. In other words, exactly as I predicted! (Although not the nice thing about the characters, which is good because they're going to be my next book, plus one.)

So I suppose it goes off to Cicada next. But I actually think it's also very much a fantasy story and could go to a genre market with a different sort of taste than F&SF, so Strange Horizons and Fantasy are three and four on the list of Places To Submit.

I got in to the Vermont College MFA program.* Happy dance!

*It's the low residency program in writing for children and young adults.

Here's me being thinky:

And now, screwing with the software even more than thinky mcfingertip is:


Apologies, but the graphics wouldn't fit in ye old typepad.

Apologies for the garbled syntax -- kind of a garbled week. It's been a nonproductive one in terms of words anyway, but I've actually been crazy motivated and just too busy to sit down and do it. FINALLY got some time and banged out a bit, and I absolutely cannot wait to write the next few chapters. I love this part of newbookland.

It's funny. I have this sort of outline that's not really an outline. It's basically a long file of story and character notes and (public domain) poetry and such that I want to maybe use at the start of different sections. And it's always amazing to me how effortlessly something that seemed like a good idea for a little bit of plot when I was typing up the notes becomes a completely different, much more interesting thing without my even noticing until I happen to be looking up something and come across the original intent. There are magical objects referenced in the notes that are completely DIFFERENT magical objects now. Better magical objects. This gives me great and mighty joy.

Yeah, I'm a nerd.

And as the green book says, the only way to really know your story is to tell it.

Here's the progress meter. I dream of the day it hits 50 percent.
11,301 / 65,000
(17.4%)

There are things about this book which scare me nigh unto death every time I let myself think about them (how political it is at heart, how big the landscape it occupies is, how much I love it): I think that's a good sign. I'm coming up on some huge set-piece events that should be truly fun to write, and I will not consider how hard they'll be to pull off until afterward. Yeah, right. If this approach has ever worked for anyone, let me know.

I'm hoping to write more later, but I'm also committed to represent my class (1993) at this year's Gov's School for the Arts graduation later in the afternoon, conveniently taking place a block from where we live. It's the 20th anniversary of the program. So I figured I'd do my little progress meter now; about 1200 new words since the last time.

Also, as my main birthday present, I'm getting a new Mac at the end of the month (when freelance $$ and time to drive up to the Apple Store in Cincy arrive), and I've been thinking about where I want my habitual writing space to be for this book, once I'm not tied to the desk. Sort of inspired (oh, hateful word) by Glen Hirshberg's writing space posts; I especially like the part about having different light. I spend so much time messing around online, or doing other types of work at desks, that the idea of having a spacial trigger for writing time hugely appeals. My office in our old place had the comfy chair in the corner and two French doors that closed it off and that was my symbol I was working, to close those doors. Nothing so handy here, but I'm thinking. Anyway, I want to come up with somewhere I like because my desk desperately needs to be replaced. And my chair stinks. But the dog has sort of claimed my corner, tin-ceiling room chair where I originally thought I'd set up shop in this house. Maybe Emma will just have to get displaced. (More likely, I will just have lots of dog hair on my back after I write.) We'll see. I'm torn about it, because I want a regular space but I also pride myself on being able to write anywhere. But, sadly, being able doesn't actually mean you are writing in all these exotic locales, like the library, the coffee shop, etc. Having a regular space means You Are Writing when you sit there. Of course, Christopher's been wanting to do writing at the coffeeshop, so I guess we could do that some too, in the evenings, post-Emma walk. But only if he can write in the evening. Fascinating as this is, I will stop now and have lunch and put on a dress and then we do the graduation and then my parents for (possibly) red velvet pre-birthday birthday cake.
10,305 / 65,000
(15.9%)

So, all the freelance work at the moment is freelanced (one bit fell through, and I'm actually glad  -- short, funny story), the grad school application is applicationed and sent (crossing of fingers! I had a dream last night in which MFA residencies are like spy school; a girl can dream), and the writing has begun again. And, well, I'm also about half a month earlier than I thought on all this (mostly given to the fallen through, and proving that one can attempt to drive oneself batcruise crazy), which is all to the good.

At some point, I really will swear off parentheticals over here.

This morning I sat down and wrote some honest to god new words. Some of them having a little fun at West Virginia's expense even.

And Christopher finished a big proposal this weekend, so we took the afternoon bye-bye to see Superman Returns (LOVED!!! Esp. Parker Posey) and then had a way too expensive early dinner. It is one hundred degrees here. And we still need to walk Miss Emma the Dog-Girl. Ouch you, Globate Climate Change.

Here's the stats:
9,124 / 65,000
(14.0%)
Llamas seen: None
A Sentence: You know the kind I mean: stories about crazy, toothless gas station owners with Pulp Fiction rooms in the back.
A La Mode Desserts Eaten: One Derby Pie
Random Research Tidbit: "Cheiron was the first and wisest of the centaurs."
Song References: One, "Jackson"

I'm working on my Vermont College MFA program application (which I already feel stupid for talking about, because, you know, I could not make it in and then you would know and think evil, evil thoughts about it) (I'm kidding, about the evil thoughts anyway) this week, since Kelly mailed off her recommendation letter already and Scott's will go out any day now. And so I've filled out the application and transcript-requested and drafted an application essay (oh, woe, I hate you) and a thrown together a "critical essay" (about ribinder's Boy Proof, based off the blog entry I did about it way back when -- I may have to formal this up a little yet). AND I've been editing the 25-page writing sample (Times New Roman, bless you for breaking this at the right place when Courier was being mean), which is actually why I'm posting here.

I know this doesn't really count, but it does, oh, it does today. I added a couple hundred words to Aztec Dance Tunes in the polishingness, so updated progress bar(!). (And really, once this stuff goes out, I can start working on ADT again; I finished a massive amount of freelance stuff over the weekend.) Without further justification:
8,425 / 65,000
(13.0%)
I know, I know. But what can I say? Thirteen's my lucky number.

So, yay, I got little bar thing code. Which I'll probably hate in a few days, as it mocks me, but hey, I've got a bit of a running start at the moment. Here's where I stand on le Aztec Dance Tunes, the YA in progress.

Chapters: Four
Chapter Titles Referencing a Gillian Welch Song: One (I DREAM A HIGHWAY)
Favorite Recently Written Sentence: I started out googling "the president is evil" and followed the trail.
Silliest Character Name: Maybelle
8,297 / 65,000
(12.8%)

Man, that's a long haul by the endish of September. But doable. And hey, I hear the equinox (22nd) is snurri's birthday, which is clearly a sign that I will make the deadline.

p.s. I wonder what it means that I decided to do this -- and to finish on the equinox -- on Solstice, without even realizing it. Insert metaphysical wiggling of fingers here.

I've decided to start keeping a little Aztec Dance Tunes progress diary over here too. (Those who have friended, do not fear -- it'll only be updated a couple of times a week.) What I really, really, really want is one of those little progress bars, you know, so many words out of the estimated total, and then I'll come up with some fun metrics. Because I don't think most of S&S's readers want to see this stuff, yet I feel compelled to keep up with it to shame myself into getting a draft done by September 22.

But I am clueless about how to find the code to do the progress bar. Help me!

My blog is at http://gwendabond.typepad.com or you can access a livejournal feed of it at http://www.livejournal.com/users/shakennstirred/

This account is just so I can post comments on LJ pages and read the comments-heavy entries easier on the Friends Page. (Do not be alarmed if suddenly friended; I'm just finally using this feature.)
